tweets.content:
Sometimes I think back to when Zhang Yiming, founder of TikTok, built the first version of Toutiao, their first flagship product, with just a handful of people in a tiny Beijing apartment.

It had a weak recsys and a clunky app.

Avg session length: just a few minutes.
A year later: 30 minutes.
Soon after: nearly 2 hours.

Then 100M DAUs.

Believe in the power of paradigm shifts

What Twitter did to The New York Times, Buzzing is doing to prediction markets.

On Buzzing, countless markets are created, covering every country, every niche. Each time you open the app, you see endless new markets, recommended just for you.

AI prediction markets.

The TikTok + Hyperliquid of prediction markets.

tweets.content:
we grew from zero to $50M ARR in <2 years, profitably
i've never publicly shared our tactics before
it's cost us over $5M to learn what I'm about to share

800-word long post on every growth hack that printed money for us

I'll cover:
1. Influencer Marketing
2. Performance Marketing vs Brand
3. User Testing
4. Dogfooding

0-10M was nearly 100% word of mouth and organic content

10-50M was still >50% word of mouth but influencer, affiliate, and referral made up the other half

But the foundation we set from 0-$10M is what allowed us to blaze past $50M

1. Influencer Marketing 101:

90% of your reach comes from <10% of content that goes viral. Your job: go broad with influencers and spend enough to find that 10% of content and formats that work. Virality is no accident - test and discover hooks, visuals, formats for each platform, understand why they work, and replicate 100x across your influencer roster.

Most startups get three things wrong:
1 - Too small budget
2 - Overly selective on creators and messaging
3 - Give up too early
Start with $10-20k/month, commit to 6 months minimum. This lets you experiment with many micro influencers and lets you test many concepts.

- List creator personas with audiences that care about your product. Be exhaustive. Influencer outreach is time-consuming. Work with a freelancer or agency if you don't have a team. DM me for recommendations.

- Offer base + viral bonus. For TikTok, have them start new accounts. New accounts can get as many views as established ones. But on new accounts creators are unburdened by their brand and can try any format.

- Test across all platforms (TikTok, IG, X, LinkedIn work for most B2B/prosumer apps).

- Track specific creators and hooks that outperform, not just channels.

- Add 'How did you hear about us' to onboarding. Calculate which channels drive leads vs just views.

- Compile every asset, video or hook that works into a guide. Once you have 20-30 winning formats, hire your top creators as consultants to train all other influencers on what angles go viral for you and why.

- Never write scripts - it becomes an ad no one watches.
Creators know their audience best.

2. Invest in brand before performance marketing

Most startups are not prepared to scale their spend because their brand and creative sucks. We had to go through an extremely expensive rebrand (both in terms of time and dollars spent) to land on something we loved. But it would have been much more expensive to skip this step.

Be relentless about testing a wide range of creatives. Whatever number of creatives you're thinking of testing, 10x it. Be bold. See what moves the needle (CAC payback, conversion rates, LTV and retention).

Once you see a particular use case resonating, build a whole funnel around it with symmetric messaging. You donâ€™t want to confuse visitors by showing them an ad with one value prop and then drop them on to a landing page with a completely different message.

3. Get users to test prototypes before you ship.

This seems trivial, but saves you from the worst startup mistake - misdirected product development.

Most startups think experimentation is for mature companies improving their funnel by 1% through a/b testing. But Gamma's founding team is early Optimizely folks. Experimentation is in our DNA.

We ran extensive user testing on platforms like voicepanel and usertesting

a. Recruited random people who make slide decks for work. They have no skin in the game and won't lie to be nice.

b. Showed them prototypes with minimal instructions and let them spend a few minutes trying things out.

c. Asked them to think out loud. The words they use to navigate, their expectations, where they get confused is gold. Combining their voice + screen actions amplifies things 10x. You really feel the pain of poor UX and overcomplicated copy.

Did this for everything - landing pages, onboarding, new features, moonshot concepts.

Always test your biggest assumptions about what people will get or like. Identify major blind spots in your prototype stage, not at the end.

Ship once you have hours of testing proof that ordinary people find it easy and useful.

4. Dogfood the hell out of your product

Either you build something that's 100x better than alternatives, or you build something else. Dogfooding makes it painfully obvious if your product isn't a 100x better.

Storytime: When we started Gamma, we had two competing ideas -
Idea 1:  a virtual office to capture in-person magic
Idea 2:  reimagining PowerPoint from the ground up (This became Gamma)

After 6 months of building and dogfooding both of them in parallel, we had a clear winner.

It wasn't about metrics or hard data.

With a virtual office, we were always competing against IRL and could never replace the magic of being together in person.

With the reimagined PowerPoint, we could imagine a product 100x better than the alternative.

Any startup can learn from our playbook.
I really hope they do.

tweets.content:
Do only large-scale market makers make money? 

Not really. Market makers can profit across markets of all sizes. In big markets, there isnâ€™t clear evidence that MMs have either a higher probability of winning or a higher order of magnitude in profits.
tweets.author: DeFiGuyLuke

tweets.content:
Are there insiders? 

Yes, but not many. If you count â€œlarge, short-term buys in the right directionâ€ as insider trades, this kind of activity does exist on Polymarket, but itâ€™s relatively rare.
tweets.author: DeFiGuyLuke

tweets.content:
Do prediction markets show foresight? 

For the most part, no. In many cases, prices flip dramatically after the outcome becomes clear. A lot of news-driven arbitrageurs simply push Polymarket prices toward the â€œcorrectâ€ level.

tweets.content:
Expanding a concept too broadly is just lazy thinking. Yeah, if you stretch it far enough then sure, crypto is all â€œprediction markets.â€

But being crypto-native is actually a very niche lifestyle. Almost every girl I know has zero interest in trading memecoins, but plenty would happily bet on when Taylor Swift will get married.

People are bullish on prediction markets because of what they represent, theyâ€™re flexible, meaningful, and cover a wide range of topics.

On the other hand, nobody really wants to trade these so-called â€œprediction marketsâ€ like mindshare indexes or tickers split into bullish vs. bearish memecoins.

Weâ€™ve been working with Dino for a while, and Fluent left a strong impression on me: a hardworking team moving in the right direction and focused on long-term value. Dino and we share many views, neither of us are fans of the old crypto playbook of farming, yapping, and chasing vanity metrics.

Instead, Fluent offers forward-looking technology that lowers barriers and empowers any developer to build, along with strategies that help apps achieve PMF and onboard users more effectively. Theyâ€™re one of the few smart and future-facing teams in crypto, and Iâ€™m excited to build the coolest consumer products together and push toward the next wave of mass adoption.

tweets.content:
Crypto just went through a chaotic phase chasing vanity metrics. Iâ€™ve seen this before in Web2: founders hacking DAU spikes, climbing app store charts, hoping for a quick acquisition (much like todayâ€™s projects scrambling for listings). More than one even told me their startup goal was simply â€œto get bought.â€

But history shows this playbook always fails. A few early exits happened, but soon the rest were left with nothing. Markets may look irrational in the short term, but theyâ€™re always rational in the long term.

If youâ€™re building in Crypto today, my advice is simple:
Focus on PMF 
Build towards revenue. It doesnâ€™t need to be day one, but the path must be clear.
Think in terms of network effects and marginal cost.

Iâ€™m crypto-native, but Iâ€™m tired of incremental â€œbetter Hyperliquidâ€ or â€œbetter lendingâ€ products. Crypto-native is a lifestyle for a small group of degens. With only a few million real on-chain MAUs and one-dimensional use cases, there isnâ€™t much room for finer segmentation. A â€œbetter Xâ€ rarely becomes a real business because almost no one needs it. We should build for a broader audience and use cryptoâ€™s low-cost financial rails to serve people outside the bubble. 

Think about the future, not the past; do that, or pick a different industry.

tweets.author: DeFiGuyLuke

tweets.content:
CT is discussing prediction markets on HIP3. Iâ€™d love to see and try it if someone builds it, but to be honest Iâ€™m not optimistic. Perps are a form of leveraged trading, and not every asset is suitable for leverage. Whether leverage works depends heavily on the underlying assetâ€™s nature.

Yes/No tokens in prediction markets arenâ€™t perpetual, linearly priced assets. Their price and liquidity can instantly drop to zero or fall 90%. This puts the leverage provider, whether itâ€™s a perp market maker or a lending protocol lender, at a structural disadvantage compared to traders. If traders win, they can amplify gains through leverage while the leverage provider only earns APY. If traders lose, the leverage provider risks massive losses from delayed liquidations, similar to a total wipeout.

Secondly, prediction market users simply donâ€™t have much demand for perps, and thatâ€™s the most important point. Iâ€™ve interviewed many users, and Polymarketâ€™s audience isnâ€™t made up of hardcore gamblers who need sophisticated financial tools. In fact, Polymarketâ€™s trading interface is extremely basic. Most users are there to trade for fun. They want more diverse and entertaining topics, not to look at MACD charts for prediction markets. The latter makes no sense, right?

Finally, except for a handful of markets with deep order books and long lifespans, most Polymarket markets expire quickly, and their order book liquidity is often lower than memecoins. That makes designing perps for them even harder.

tweets.content:
3. Build an ecosystem, not just a product
Our biggest mistake last time was thinking in terms of â€œproduct.â€

Yes, we had a interesting DeFi mechanism.
Yes, the UI looked great.
Yes, the use case was real.

But we lacked the upstream and downstream.
We didnâ€™t build an incentive network.
We lacked other people who could make money with us.

As a result, once we got past the 0-to-1 stage, growth quickly plateaued.

This time, Buzzing isnâ€™t just a product, itâ€™s an ecosystem.

A place where people play different roles, bring different skills, and earn in different ways.

Because in the long run, itâ€™s ecosystems, not just products, that create real momentum.
tweets.author: DeFiGuyLuke

tweets.content:
2. Donâ€™t make your LPs think
In our last project, I spent a ridiculous amount of time explaining how our LP model worked.
How it was different from Uniswap.
What impermanent loss was.
How the payout structure worked.
None of it landed.

Weâ€™re in the era of lazy money.
No one wants to read a whitepaper. No one wants to deeply understand a custom PnL curve.
Your LP mechanism needs to be explainable in one sentence.

Hereâ€™s how others do it:
* Uniswap: Hold altcoin + stablecoin. Price drops, add more. Price rises, take profit. Like grid trading.
* GLP: A crypto index + lend to traders for leverage.
* HLP: Automated market making, youâ€™re the traderâ€™s counterparty. If they lose, you win.
Ethena: A funding rate arbitrage fund.

Buzzing LP: Youâ€™ll see
tweets.author: DeFiGuyLuke

tweets.content:
1. Donâ€™t create a new asset class
New asset classes always sound exciting.
â€œThis is crypto â€” we can trade anything!â€
Trade time, mindshare, Twitter profilesâ€¦ everything on-chain.
But the truth is, getting people to adopt new trading habits is insanely hard.

Trading, at its core, is about linking possible future outcomes to price movements. That mental model takes time to form.

For example: I know BTC is trading around $120K right now. Based on macro trends, policy news, or technical indicators, I can make a guess about what happens tomorrow.
But can anyone tell me what BTCâ€™s mindshare is today? Or whatâ€™s likely to move it up or down tomorrow?

In our last project, we were building markets around a brand-new kind of asset. Even though it felt pretty close to ERC-20s, in practice, it was almost impossible to get users to build habits around it.

This time, weâ€™re working in a space with clear and proven user demand â€” prediction markets.

tweets.content:
A fantastic interview, definitely worth a read!

Iâ€™m not your typical Crypto guy. When I first entered the space, I only held BTC/ETH and focused on delta-neutral strategies with a very low-risk preference. I wasnâ€™t keen on altcoins or memecoins. Even now, I still donâ€™t hold any altcoins outside of DeFi, but memecoins have changed my perspective.

The interesting thing about memecoins is that, compared to pure investments (or speculation), they carry more cultural significance. Trading memecoins isnâ€™t much different from trading altcoins, but itâ€™s undeniably more fun. The magic of the Crypto space lies in the fact that Crypto is an ideologyâ€”an ideology that can be monetized, making it easier to understand and amplifying its influence.

Pump.fun feels like TikTokâ€”it enables the power of UGC. What Pump.fun did reminds me of my work at Kwai, which was the biggest competitor of TikTok in China and entered the short video field earlier than TikTok.

Although my view on memecoins has changed significantly, I still rarely trade them (my colleague @0xcryptoblack , however, is the king of memes). For me, meme culture often has a high entry barrier, and the meme space tends to have a lot of market manipulation and noise.

That was until I discovered prediction markets. Prediction markets are currently the type of product in the Crypto space that align most closely with my preferences. I now spend more time on prediction markets than on delta-neutral strategies. The cultural fields covered by prediction markets are more mainstream, with lower entry barriers and less speculation and manipulation. I believe thereâ€™s more room for exploration here.

Although both prediction markets and memecoins are, in a way, forms of 'information trading,' that doesnâ€™t mean prediction markets are similar to memecoins. In my view, prediction markets are the opposite of memecoins, they have entirely different user profiles and dissemination mechanisms. Personally, Iâ€™m bearish on any â€œprediction markets version pump.funâ€. The user of prediction market  are not-so-typical Crypto guy, as described in the interview.

Similarly, passive LPs know nothings about current market dynamics until designer provide it. The best way to designing an AMM is like optimizing an AI model: start with a simple or existing curve and feed it market information through the parameters.

Bubbly Finance @BubblyFinance  has officially launched and introduced Hyper Liquid Points! Right now, the price of Hyper Liquid Points is just $4â€”the lowest across all pre-market . Donâ€™t miss outâ€”grab your points today!

But wait, there are more reasons why you should use Bubbly Finance. Bubbly Finance is a pre-market platform based on an AMM, which has liquidity pools that make Bubbly unique.

Previous pre-market protocols, like @WhalesMarket  and its forks, were peer-to-peer based. This approach presents two major problems:

One major issue is that the efficiency of trading is extremely low. On Whales Market, buyers buy points or pre-launch tokens much like buying NFTs on OpenSea. This results in a poor user experience and weak liquidity. It doesnâ€™t make sense to trade fungible assets in the same way as NFTs.

Another issue with Whales Market is that you can only "buy," but you can't trade. After purchasing, you're forced to hold that position until the TGE; you can't sell to realize profits during a pump. The worst part is that you can only earn 2x, even if Hyper Liquid goes to the moon after the TGE, because the seller might default.

In my humble opinion, all these negative experiences stem from the peer-to-peer model. Buyers are limited to a specific counterparty, which causes them to lose flexibility. If we use a peer-to-pool model in the pre-market, we can address all these issues and fundamentally improve efficiency. It could be the Uniswap moment for the pre-market. An idea just came to mind...

So we built @BubblyFinance. The journey wasnâ€™t easyâ€”converting from a peer-to-peer model to a peer-to-pool model was far more complex than it might seem, but we did it. Now, with Bubbly, you can trade Hyper Liquid Points with the same simplicity youâ€™d expect from Uniswap. You can buy the dip and sell the top, riding the waves until the TGE. No need to worry about your funds being locked, and your profits aren't limited to just 2x.
